a more qualitative view of some
of the people that I think,

2686.19.text:
If any of you guys follow
business literature,

2689.43.text:
I spoke with Dan
Pink, with Tom Peters,

2692.79.text:
with Robert Cialdini
with David Allen,

2695.59.text: as I mentioned, with Seth Godin.

2698.30.text: So they were pretty cool folks.

2701.76.text:
And then in other fields, I
also drew from them as well.

2707.35.text:
I was mostly trying to
tell a different story.

2713.25.text:
And a lot of the factors
that you point out I

2716.54.text:
can sort of see in play when I
look at some successful people.

2721.22.text:
But I'm interested
in some factors that

2723.07.text:
also seem to often pop up
that you didn't mention,

2725.61.text:
and curious where
you fit them in,

2727.78.text: things that I often see pop up.

2730.61.text:
You mentioned with a
couple of your people

2732.86.text:
that oh, all of a
sudden, out of the blue,

2734.70.text:
there was the avian flu, and
then bang, he was a superstar.

2738.38.text: So there's the role of luck.

2739.55.text:
There's the role of not
just your social network,

2741.91.text:
but having the right people
in your social network,

2744.05.text:
the powerful people,
the ones who actually

2747.80.text:
And finally, there
is this dynamic

2750.74.text:
that everybody else is
trying to stand out, too,

2753.37.text:
and so you're sort of in a sea
of competition of everybody

2755.79.text:
trying to stand out, which
you sort of alluded to.

2758.41.text:
But beyond the general
advice, how do you

2761.72.text: pop out to the top of that?

2763.17.text: So a lot of factors at play.

2769.12.text:
have nearly a whole chapter on
the role of luck in the book.

2772.41.text:
So I hope you've been
able to grab a copy.

2775.26.text:
But I'll tell you guys
briefly, luck is actually

2777.64.text:
one of the more interesting
elements of this,

2781.30.text:
and one that oftentimes I
actually close the talk with.

2785.64.text:
So here in Cambridge,
actually, very close to here,

2790.01.text:
there's a venture capital
firm called Cue Ball Partners.

2794.45.text:
It's run by a guy named Anthony
Chan and some of his partners.

2798.59.text:
A few years ago they wrote a
book called "Heart, Smarts,

2803.93.text:
It came out, actually, from
Harvard Business Review

2806.30.text:
Press, which published my
first book, "Reinventing You."

2811.30.text:
did a pretty wide-ranging
study of entrepreneurs

2816.66.text:
And they broke people down
into four personality types,

2821.80.text:
And you can even go
to their website.

2823.34.text:
They have something called
the EAT, the Entrepreneurial

2825.66.text:
Assessment Test, which
is kind of fun to take.

2828.18.text:
And it shows you what your
dominant personality type is.

2832.26.text:
The first three, to me, make
fairly intuitive sense, right?

2836.49.text:
Hearts driven, smarts
driven, guts driven.

2839.53.text:
We can all imagine
scenarios where

2843.03.text:
people are able to succeed
because of those qualities.

2846.26.text:
The one that was a little
bit more mystifying

2851.91.text:
But it turns out if you peel
it back, interestingly enough,

2855.28.text:
the research begins to
show, of course luck

2858.51.text:
is something we can only
attribute post facto, right?

2861.74.text:
You don't know in the moment
that something is lucky.

2864.89.text:
It's kind of like, oh,
after it plays out,

2869.07.text:
What does it look like
in the moment, however?

2871.78.text:
It turns out that
lucky entrepreneurs,

2875.16.text:
or top executives, are
people who actually

2878.97.text:
have a different personality
type than the other types

2884.55.text:
They are typically
more laid back,

2886.84.text:
and they exhibit, in large
quantities, two really

2891.36.text:
important attributes
that all of us

2894.26.text:
can develop more
of in our lives.

2896.91.text:
One is curiosity, and
the other is humility.

2900.66.text:
And the reason that this plays
in is, so many of the people,

2904.24.text:
so many of the
successful professionals

2905.89.text:
that they profiled,
they have a mission.

2909.84.text:
Part of what makes
them successful

2911.34.text:
is they're so focused, they say,
I'm going to go to this meeting

2914.43.text:
and I'm going to meet the
head of marketing for Ford.

2917.74.text:
Or I'm going to go
to this meeting,

2919.20.text:
and I'm going to meet
venture capitalists

2920.91.text:
who will give me my Series A
funding, or whatever it is.

2924.43.text:
But they have this
idea in their head,

2927.28.text:
and if they don't see
things that loo like that,

2931.99.text:
they will barrel through,
whereas a lucky entrepreneur

2936.53.text:
or executive is
someone who is far more

2939.12.text:
willing to just sit back and
say, oh, this person seems

2944.24.text:
And they wait, and they
see how it plays out,

2948.74.text:
And they are curious
enough to want

2950.36.text:
to learn about that person,
and they are humble enough

2953.84.text:
to realize that
they have something

2958.68.text:
And years later, that is what
plays out and turns to luck.

2963.11.text:
So I think that that's
one of the coolest things

2966.30.text:
that I learned from that
book and from that research.

2969.72.text:
Also, Richard Wiseman
is a psychologist

2971.97.text:
who's done a lot of
research into luck.

2974.99.text:
One suggestion
that he has, which

2976.47.text:
you guys can apply
if you're interested,

2979.14.text:
there's a factor that comes into
play with almost all humans,

2983.95.text:
which is that we
really tend to be drawn

2987.84.text: to people who are like us.

2991.34.text:
It's not necessarily good
in terms of diversity

2995.66.text:
And so Richard Wiseman
actually talked about somebody

2999.57.text:
And this guy, the way
that he broke out of that

3002.43.text:
is that he made a
rule for himself,

3004.14.text:
if he was going to a networking
event or a cocktail party,

3006.74.text:
that he would pick
a color in advance,

3009.49.text:
and he would only talk to people
wearing that color so that he

3013.01.text:
would be forced to choose
different people than he might

3017.89.text:
And that's a way to
increase our luck.

3020.39.text:
So I think it's a
really rich topic.

3025.09.text:
Let's talk more afterwards
about your other points,

3029.43.text:
Ma'am, what was your
question or comment?

3031.34.text:
AUDIENCE: Thank you
very much for this talk.

3034.74.text:
So I'm just following

3036.66.text:
said about being
flexible and open,

3040.61.text:
which is kind of the natural

3043.64.text:
But when you first said
earlier about being deliberate,

3046.61.text:
I said, uh, that's what
I need to introduce.

3048.70.text:
So how do you reconcile being
flexible and seeing what's

3051.95.text:
out there, and allowing yourself
to see the possibilities

3055.43.text:
with being deliberate
and actually moving

3057.16.text:
in the direction
that you want to go?

3061.68.text:
And in many ways, it's similar
to the going wide versus going

3067.64.text:
I would say in
general, we can play

3070.05.text:
choose to play to our strengths,
whatever our strength is.

3074.12.text:
However, there is a way
to bring them together.

3076.55.text:
I mean, certainly in terms of
a lot of the career research

3079.99.text:
that I do, one piece
of advice that I

3083.26.text:
would give to the
professionals that I

3086.59.text:
counsel and work with in
my consulting business,

3091.36.text: But treat it as a hypothesis.

3093.34.text:
It's something that
you're moving toward so

3095.91.text:
that you are moving
towards something,

3097.99.text:
so that you have some
degree of forward momentum.

3100.30.text:
But don't allow
it to lock you in.

3102.78.text:
If you see something over
to the side that is better,

3105.78.text:
or is more interesting, or is
something that you literally

3108.32.text:
just could not have predicted
because you couldn't have even

3111.34.text:
seen it until you reached the
halfway point in your march

3115.43.text:
toward that new thing, then
feel free to veer off and go

3119.74.text:
But always have something
that at least provisionally

3123.22.text:
you're working
toward, so that you're

3125.03.text:
able to enjoy the benefits
of forward momentum

3127.84.text:
and seeing things
from new vistas

3129.56.text:
that you previously
wouldn't have been able to.

3136.11.text:
AUDIENCE: So my question

an idea on your own like

3152.93.text:
The reason why Google can make

3157.19.text:
as compared to, say, the

3159.40.text:
in academia, is because

3162.74.text:
and they have more people,

3165.63.text:
and they have more

3168.11.text:
And so if have

3173.66.text:
did you see anything about

3175.70.text:
sense for me to try to build

3179.14.text:
and own the idea to

3181.74.text:
so that then I can make it into

3185.49.text:
Or is it more practical
to try to pitch it

3190.70.text:
But then how do you
build credibility

3194.16.text:
around the idea instead of
having somebody just toss it

3198.11.text:
So I guess going on
your own versus working

3204.53.text:
So there's actually a
couple of questions at play.

3206.78.text:
One is the personal
branding question.

3209.68.text:
How do you get known
and get credibility

3212.72.text:
as being the driving force
behind a certain idea?

3216.03.text:
And then the other
is the question of,

3219.57.text:
where is the best home
for that idea in terms

3223.66.text:
of operationalizing
it, and actually making

3226.18.text:
sure that it has the resources
necessary to be successful.

3232.14.text:
In the Silicon Valley ecosystem,
acqui-hires are a big thing

3236.95.text:
now, where companies,
as you guys well know,

3241.36.text:
large companies will
snap up a smaller company

3244.45.text:
because they want the
development talent.

3246.24.text:
And they will shutter the
projects with impunity,

3249.05.text:
and say, OK, fellas, now
you're working on this.

3255.70.text:
So I think that in a
technical sense, about what

3258.86.text:
is necessary for the
success of an idea,

3262.12.text:
I think that it's important
to keep in mind a few things.

3264.74.text:
Number one, is it feasible
to do the idea on your own?

3268.86.text:
Sometimes, literally,
it's not, because you

3271.09.text:
need to have data or
access to other resources

3274.80.text:
that only a big
company could provide.

3276.93.text:
If you realize that in
three months, or six months,

3280.14.text:
or a year, you were going to be
hitting a wall that you can't

3283.47.text:
surmount because you literally
don't have access to the tools

3287.16.text:
you need, then it probably
does fundamentally

3289.89.text:
need to be done within the
confines of a larger system.

3294.05.text:
If you do decide to
partner with a company,

3298.45.text:
then it's a question
of making sure

3299.91.text:
that you have contracts
and legal protections,

3302.76.text:
as much as you possibly can,
that validate this idea is not

3306.91.text:
going to be shuttered,
and that you have ways

3309.99.text:
of protecting it and keeping
it as an ongoing concern,

3313.05.text:
perhaps with a sort
of special mandate.

3316.43.text:
When it comes to
your personal brand,

3318.14.text:
one of the things
that I'll advise--

3319.64.text:
and I'll just wrap up because
we're getting the curtain

3323.30.text:
warning here momentarily-- but
one of the things that I think

3328.57.text:
is important for all
of us to be aware of

3331.36.text:
is the amazing resource
that is content creation.

3336.59.text:
Sometimes people come to me
and they say, well, you know,

3340.51.text:
But I don't want to talk
about them because someone

3345.24.text:
And you hear this
a lot from people.

3348.66.text:
And so my asterisk
on this, OK, sure.

3350.86.text:
If you have this amazing,
patentable engineering

3355.72.text:
Go patent it, go do that,
go protect that first.

3358.70.text:
But if you have
an idea, and it's

3360.26.text:
an idea about the nature
of leadership or something

3363.66.text: like that, you can't patent it.

3366.16.text:
But it doesn't go anywhere
if you don't talk about it.

3370.95.text:
Is there going to be a risk
that someone might steal it?

3374.11.text:
But I will tell you the very
best insurance against it

3378.39.text:
is for you to be everywhere
talking about it, because if I

3381.95.text:
came to you and
said, hey, I have

3384.09.text:
a really great idea for a book
about women's empowerment.

3387.55.text:
It's called "Lean In," you
would laugh in my face,

3391.05.text:
and you'd say, I
think that's been

3392.89.text:
done by Sheryl Sandberg, Dorie,
and it doesn't go any further.

3400.01.text:
And so the antidote to
anyone stealing your ideas,

3404.28.text:
or your idea dying, for that
matter, is to get the word out.

3408.60.text:
And so I would say if you want
to be known and associated

3410.97.text:
for something, go
nuts with blogging,

3413.68.text:
with content creation,
being out there,

3415.57.text:
touting it, so that your name
is almost inextricably entwined

3419.66.text:
And then that way, whether
you get acquired, partner

3422.07.text:
with somebody, or not, you're
going to be known as the go

3427.64.text:
So thank you so much
for your question.

3430.01.text:
Thank you, everybody,
for having me.
